message_1: What is the dimension of the vector space $\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))$, where $\mathbb{P}^1$ is the complex projective line and $\mathcal{O}(n-2)$ is the line bundle associated to the divisor $(n-2)\cdot\infty$, where $\infty$ is a fixed point in $\mathbb{P}^1$ and $n$ is a positive integer?
message_2:
To compute the dimension of the vector space $\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))$, we can use the Riemann-Roch theorem for the complex projective line $\mathbb{P}^1$. The Riemann-Roch theorem states that for a line bundle $\mathcal{L}$ on $\mathbb{P}^1$, we have:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^0(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{L})) - \text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{L})) = \text{deg}(\mathcal{L}) + 1$.

Here, $\text{deg}(\mathcal{L})$ denotes the degree of the line bundle $\mathcal{L}$, which in our case is $n-2$. So we have:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^0(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) - \text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = (n-2) + 1$.

Now, we know that $\text{H}^0(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))$ is the space of global sections of the line bundle $\mathcal{O}(n-2)$. Since $\mathcal{O}(n-2)$ is a line bundle of degree $n-2$, it has $n-1$ global sections if $n-2 \geq 0$, and no global sections if $n-2 < 0$. Therefore, we have:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^0(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = \begin{cases} n-1 & \text{if } n-2 \geq 0 \\ 0 & \text{if } n-2 < 0 \end{cases}$.

Now, we can solve for $\text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2)))$:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = \text{dim}(\text{H}^0(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) - (n-1)$.

If $n-2 \geq 0$, we have:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = (n-1) - (n-1) = 0$.

If $n-2 < 0$, we have:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = 0 - (n-1) = 1-n$.

So, the dimension of the vector space $\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))$ is:

$\text{dim}(\text{H}^1(\mathbb{P}^1,\mathcal{O}(n-2))) = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } n-2 \geq 0 \\ 1-n & \text{if } n-2 < 0 \end{cases}$.
